naloxone.title: Administering Naloxone
naloxone.summary: Steps to reverse an opioid overdose until emergency responders arrive.

steps.title: Check for responsiveness
steps.details: Shout the person's name, rub their sternum with your knuckles, and look for slow or absent breathing.

steps.title: Call emergency services
steps.details: Dial 000 immediately. Put the phone on speaker so you can follow the operator's instructions while helping.

steps.title: Administer naloxone
steps.details: Peel back the package, place the nozzle in one nostril, and press the plunger firmly. Use one device per dose.

steps.title: Support breathing
steps.details: Lay the person on their back, tilt the head, lift the chin, and give one breath every 5 seconds if they are not breathing.

steps.title: Monitor and repeat if needed
steps.details: If there is no response after 2-3 minutes, administer another naloxone dose. Stay until help arrives.

aftercare: Place the person in the recovery position once they are breathing on their own.
Explain what happened—they may feel disoriented or agitated.
Naloxone wears off in 30-90 minutes. Watch for return of overdose signs.

saferUse.title: Safer-Use Tips
saferUse.summary: Practical harm-reduction strategies to lower overdose risk.
tips: Avoid using alone—arrange a trusted contact or phone call check-in.
Start low, go slow when using a new batch or source.
Test a small amount first and wait to feel the effects before taking more.
Keep naloxone and breathing barriers with your kit at all times.
Use clean equipment and rotate sites to reduce infection risk.
Store substances safely away from children and pets.
